item.title: Review: Pixels
item.description:
Dear Adam Sandler, Acolyte of Baal And Star of PIXELS,

Adam Sandler is the Antichrist Adam Sandler is the Antichrist, Adam Sandler is the Antichrist. Adam Sandler is the Antichrist: Adam Sandler is the Antichrist; Adam Sandler is the Antichrist; Adam Sandler is the Antichrist.

p>

item.title: Feature: The Value of a Veteran Filmmaker
item.description:
Dear Freshman Filmmakers,
Is Hollywood's rush to give young directors the key to the blockbuster kingdom robbing them of their chance to grow as artists?p>

item.title: Review: Trainwreck

Dear Alison Jones, Casting Director,

Thank you for taking a chance.

item.title: Review: Big Game
item.description:
Dear Jalmari Helander, Writer/Director,

I didn’t like your movie Big Game very much, but my real argument with you is less about the quality of your particular film and more to do with a larger issue.

p>

item.title: Feature: A Conversation with Big Game Director Jalmari Helander
item.description:
Dear false,
C. Redmond speaks with Finnish director Jalmari Helander about breaking into the Hollywood game, what’s wrong with most action movies today, and who he wants to make the next big action star.p>

item.title: Review: Terminator: Genysis
item.description:
Dear Ronna Kress, Casting,

It would be unfair to place the responsibility for the fiasco that is Terminator: Genisys entirely at your feet. It’s a film whose shortcomings are so varied, so composite, that they defy easy categorization. The special effects are degenerative—somehow less thrilling, less real, than they were twenty-three (!) years ago in Terminator 2: Judgment Day. The script unfolds like something the producers acquired through Fiverr—it has all the nuance and surprise of a crowdsourced piece of fan fiction. The production feels small-scale, constrained, cheap. Even the music – which occasionally pays tribute to Brad Feidel’s clamorous carillon theme – is so vacuous and forgettable that the film may as well have been scored by radio static.

p>
